p.seg: I Humbly lay before your Highnefs Feet
an Unhappy Favourite, but 'tis in Your
Power to make him no longer fb; Not his
Queens Repentance y nor her Tears cou'd
Refcue him from the Malice of his Enemies ,
nor from the violence of a moft unfortunate
Death; but your Highnefs with this unfpeak-
able Favour, and fb Divine a Condefcention in
ProteQing this once pitty'd Hero, will make him
li\*e Eternally ; and thofe who cou'd fcarce be-
hold him on the Stage without weeping, when
they (hall fee him thus exalted, will all turn en-
vious of his Fortune, which they can never think
deplorable while he is graced by your Highnels.
For my own part, 1 tremble to exprels my
Thanks in lb mean Language,, but much more
when I wou'd pay my Tribute of juft Praifes to
your Highnels ; 'tis not to be attempted by any
Pea, Heaven has done it to a Miracle in Your
own Perlbn, where are Written Co many admi-
rable Characters, fuch Illuftrious Beauties on a
Body [o Divinely fram'd, that there is none [o
dull and ignorant, that cannot read *em plainly;
And when You vouchfafe to caft your Eyes on
thofe beneath You, they fpeak their own Excel-
lencies with greater Art and Eloquence, and
attradt more Admiration than ever Virgil did in
his Divineft Flight of Fancy, then Ovid in {peak-
ing of hisPrincels, or Affelles in drawing of his
Venm ;, Nor are Your Virtues, or Your Royal
Blood lefs admirable^-lpr ung from the Ineftima-
ble Fountain of lb many Illuftrious Plantagenets,
that I Hand amazrd at the Mighty nels of the Sub-
bed which I havechofen; befides the awful Ge-
nius of your Highnels bids me beware how X
come too near, left IProphane lb many Incom-
parable Perfedions in fo Sacred a Shrine as your
Higlinefs Per fon, where You ought to be ador'd 3
and not ieen : For, like the Antient jews in their
Religious Worflhip., 'tis a Favour forme tore-
main on the outwarS fteps^ and not approach
nigh the Vail where the Crowd never come; This^
Moft Illuftrious Princeis, ought to check my
Hand, leaft in attempting your Highnels Cha-
rade^ my Apprehenfion of the Excellence of
the Sub) ed^and the Danger of milcarrying^ftiould
make my Fancy fink beneath fo Glorious a Bur-
then;. Therefore I will forbear troubling your
Highnefs any further with the Raftinefs of my
Zeal; nor dare I be dictated any longer by it 3
but will Conclude, in hopes that, when hereafter
I may chance to Record the Memory of a Prin-
ce/^ whole Beauty, Fortune and Merits are grea-
ter thmiHomer ever feign d, or Tap) Copy'd, il
may have leave to draw her Pattern from your;
Highnefe, and when that is done, the reft of my
Lifefhallbe employe! in Prayers for your Eter-
nal Happine% which be pleased to Interpret. a
